creditline: The Allen and Kathy Lenzmeier Endowment for Art Acquisition
description: torso and arms of a woman wearing a sweater, skirt, and shirt with horizontal stripes of various widths, in front of a plaid fabric panel, holding a framed photograph of a young woman wearing a headscarf and vertically striped blouse, with a horizontal line across her cheeks and nose and geometric designs on her cheeks
signed: on back in pencil: Retrato Seri / Desiento de Sonora 1979 / Graciela Iturbide / Copia de éproca
text: Mexican photographer Graciela Iturbide is known for her groundbreaking documentary work among the Indigenous communities of Mexico. Bringing a feminist lens to her practice, Iturbide has created a large and varied body of work representing a range of traditions, rituals, and everyday experiences relevant to Mexican women and families. Balanced in their composition, playful in their subject matter, striking in their tonal range, these photographs stand as prime examples of Iturbide’s talents as photographer and printer.
title: Retrato Seri
